advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DESKTOP & PORTABLE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD APRIL 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"compare!"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"128k=2000f<br> Better know it before buying a 64k"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Despite the M20 was neither software nor hardware compatible with any other computer, Olivetti had to prove that it had more computing power at a smaller pice than any competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERTISING PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>DEC Advertises its range of networking products.<p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here are the 20 questions :-)<br><font color="#666666"> If you're looking for your first home computer, may we make a suggestion.<br> Tear out this page.<br> And ask these questions of every computer you look at.<br> 1) Is the basic price reason­able, say under £180?<br> 2) Does it work with a monitor as well as with an ordinary UHF TV?<br> 3) Does it include a basic training manual that doesn't require a science degree to understand?<br> 4) Does it have colour?<br> 5) And sound?<br> 6) Does it take cassettes?<br> 7) And cartridges?<br> 8) And can you operate them with joysticks working directly off the basic unit?<br> 9) Does it have a profes­sional quality keyboard that's guaranteed for twenty million de­pressions (and no headaches)?<br> 10) Does it have colour graphics that are capable of producing detailed pictures?<br> 11) Is the case robust enough to stand up to the kids?<br> ­12) Does it use a standard language that's not a million, miles away from English?<br> 13) Is there an expanding range of high quality sofrware available from the makers?<br> 14) Does the software in­clude educational programs for adults as well as the very young?<br> 15) And is there sofrware sophisticated enough to satisfy the experts?<br> 16) Does it use the most up to date technology, for instance the 6809E microprocessor?<br> 17) Will it drive a standard printer directly from the basic unit?<br> 18) Is it made in the UK?<br> 19) And for the basic price will I get an easily accessible, yet large memory of at least 32K?<br> 20) Or willI have to add lots of extras (and lots of money for that much?<br> After you've finished pester­ing every computer salesman in sight, compare your answers to these, Courtesy of the Dragon 32 (this is,after all, an ad for the Dragon)<br> Questions 1-19. Yes,yes,yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes and yes.<br> Question 20. No.<br> If you're thinking that that's a lot of computer for the money. you'd be right.<br> However, when you come to read the handbook you'll soon realise that somethings missing. The jargon usually asso­ciated with computers.<br> You see every part of the Dragon has been carefully designed to be easily under­stood,even by total beginners. Yet it has all the features an expert could want Just ask it. </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR 'MOBILE' COURSE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Epson QX-10 advert appeared in January 1983. It took eight pages and explained the advantages of the Valdoc system, the benefits of the CP/M operating system compatibility, and the advanced hardware concepts. <br><br> In conclusion, it said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The most important component is you</b><br> You don't buy a computer for how "smart" it is. You buy one for how smart it makes you.<br> The Epson QX-10 was conceived, designed, engineered and built with just one thought in mind: to vastly expand your ability to see, to think, to create with a system that acts as a natural extension of the human mind.<br> The QX-10 is not a computer designed to play games, although it plays games as well as any and better than most.<br> It's a computer for people who think.<br> And who want to think better.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with 16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br> To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Junya Kubota </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual floppy drive version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer is the successor of the Luxor ABC 80
There were several successors to the ABC800, most notably the ABC802 with built-in small 9" monitor and the ABC806 with more memory and more advanced 512x240x16 graphics.
The ABC 800 series was also sold by Facit under the DTC (DeskTop Computer) name, in a darker enclosure. _______________________

emulator.description: MESS also emulates the ABC-800 Serie computers
emulator.name: MESS

computer.graphics: 240 x 240 dots in four out of eight possible colours
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke with function keys and numeric keypad
computer.name: ABC 800 Series

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Video and power supply connector. The power is supplied by the monitor<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Dual serial port<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Floppy drive unit controller card<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Reset switch<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The electronic part is made of 3 cards:<br> • CPU/RAM/ROM card, the largest one,<br> • Text Video card, at right,<br> • Graphics video card, at center. <br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 32 KB main RAM chips (16x4116)<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> 32 KB ROM chips (8x2732 EPROM's)<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 16 KB graphics video RAM chips (32x2114). Will be replaced later with 16x4116<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 6845 video CRT controller (same as first IBM PC mono & colour cards)<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Power regulators box, the power is supplied by the monitor<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Audio amplifier and loudspeaker<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Z80A processor. Most of the Z80 family chips came from Sharp<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE LUXOR ABC 802</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ABC 802 can run either under CP/M or UFD-DOS (User File Directory DOS, the OS from Luxor). It appears to have the same characteristics than the 800. The ABC 802 was followed by the ABC 806</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE LUXOR ABC 806</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ABC 806 had 192 KB RAM which could be used as a RAM DISK.</blockquote>
